newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - June 11.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - June 11.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The conflict between the police and the Constitution Drafting Assembly over the detention of criminal suspects has developed into a war of words between the deputy police chief and prosecutors. Police General Salang Bunnag and Thanaboon Chiranuwat, his legal adviser have accused Kanit na Nakhon, the attorney-general and an assembly member, of initiating the idea to limit to 24 hours the detention period. (BANGKOK POST)

- The Interior Ministry's news analysing centre has begun its around-the clock, fully equipped operation despite heavy criticism from journalists, officials say. At the same time, cabinet members insist that the centre, which is under the newly-formed media monitoring committee, is not established to target the media. (THE NATION) (BANGKOK POST)

- The Cabinet has approved the creation of a new labour committee which will be given the authority to determine labour policy and arbitrate industrial relations cases and labour disputes involving foreign-owned companies. The decision follows a spate of foreign company closures, particularly in labour-intensive fields such as property development, textile manufacturing and food industries. (THE NATION)

- Financial authorities have turned up the heat on currency speculators, preventing them from obtaining baht to cover their short-term positions. The Bank of Thailand has imposed what it calls temporary steps to control banks' custodian services. (BANGKOK POST) (THE NATION)

- Some 1,000 marble and granite-quarrying mine owners and workers from five provinces yesterday converged on Government House to protest at the Cabinet's decision to impose excise tax on their products, reflecting growing policy diferences between the finance and industry ministers. (THE NATION)
